CE5A5A1A524D4457BDE2D6B4F6710A69.description: Use effective, factual descriptions of appearance, concrete images, shifting perspectives and vantage points, and sensory details.

D86909CC4EB34D4F98FFD7AF3751F3F5.description:
Establish clearly the speaker's relationship with that subject (e.g., dispassionate
observation, personal involvement).

E69DA109E37C4017BE40D83FF91C61F4.description: Establish clearly the speaker's point of view on the subject of the presentation.

51E0BE31970E4DE4ADEE5CFC6217535D.description: Anticipate and address the listener's concerns and counterarguments.

B850498369E44CFEA0BA2515C89BC6C1.description:
Clarify and defend positions with precise and relevant evidence, including facts,
expert opinions, quotations, expressions of commonly accepted beliefs, and logical
reasoning.

5A0A0154278B46359F34806C1D9FFFB4.description: Structure ideas and arguments in a coherent, logical fashion.

0CE20C216B344AA098AB7588679492AD.description: Deliver persuasive arguments (including evaluation and analysis of problems and solutions and causes and effects):

77B692D2DCA948DFABFF4B048917C17C.description: Identify and assess the impact of perceived ambiguities, nuances, and complexities within the text.

9351C07E5ED74111B765A8E13048B009.description: Demonstrate awareness of the author's use of stylistic devices and an appreciation of the effects created.

0AE3E15718AF4A3BB9E5E332F9E367C1.description: Support important ideas and viewpoints through accurate and detailed references to the text or to other works.

CAFA19511E934DF8B886C076C223CD51.description: Advance a judgment demonstrating a comprehensive grasp of the significant ideas of works or passages (i.e., make and support warranted assertions about the text).

F9864E05A0EC41DFAB237635530F5A6E.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of the interview.

354DBCD14D024301ACCF56D0D9E79FC2.description: Demonstrate knowledge of the subject or organization.

027F73AD924C43899A6443996F567682.description: Respond correctly and effectively to questions.

E872DFC6804544BA9C4DE60493D23A8B.description: Use language that conveys maturity, sensitivity, and respect.

3E99C5F00BE64F60BE0F140541648A36.description: Use technical terms and notations accurately.

4908658A9A1E4275AD924DF3C8BB2D1C.description: Anticipate and address the listener's potential misunderstandings, biases, and expectations.

269C7E8E51AE46E78510C6562FF9D8AA.description:
Include visual aids by employing appropriate technology to organize and display
information on charts, maps, and graphs.

86FF19BB9D5B4CDEB892B4D1D352C577.description:
Make distinctions between the relative value and significance of specific data, facts,
and ideas.

63B2D2FCFD01437889BAA1D0D438811E.description: Convey information and ideas from primary and secondary sources accurately and coherently.

BA291A7D8A07449AB93F8E5403E18F56.description: Marshal evidence in support of a thesis and related claims, including information on all relevant perspectives.

31536E34DC1745F589A8FEF30845F281.description: Pace the presentation of actions to accommodate time or mood changes.

050297922C234756BA61FC2DECC8DCF7.description: Describe with concrete sensory details the sights, sounds, and smells of a scene and the specific actions, movements, gestures, and feelings of characters.

A7CB0784B8E94B1BBF1F12700B51B24E.description: Locate scenes and incidents in specific places.

474FF995F9A042B89C4E3FDBBA7C61AF.description: Narrate a sequence of events and communicate their significance to the audience.

CD355F78B6DD4F59AED8534C3D963877.description:
Using the speaking strategies of grades nine and ten outlined in Listening and Speaking
Standard 1.0, students:

3C67BDE7BE8A4725976B4B9AAF764B7E.description: Students deliver polished formal and extemporaneous presentations that combine the traditional rhetorical strategies of narration, exposition, persuasion, and description. Student speaking demonstrates a command of standard American English and the organizational and delivery strategies outlined in Listening and Speaking Standard 1.0.

C38889CB22E8434386A3E275FE33459B.description:
Identify the aesthetic effects of a media presentation and evaluate the techniques used to
create them (e.g., compare Shakespeare's Henry V with Kenneth Branagh's 1990 film
version).

13BF5EAA00EC4D8784A5D1105E091105.description:
Analyze the types of arguments used by the speaker, including argument by causation,
analogy, authority, emotion, and logic.

60194144210E4CDEAB0425D25CDC03B5.description: Evaluate the clarity, quality, effectiveness, and general coherence of a speaker's important points, arguments, evidence, organization of ideas, delivery, diction, and syntax.

9CB8C2E97D4A4CD0AB5D0427212EF122.description: Assess how language and delivery affect the mood and tone of the oral communication and make an impact on the audience.

741800A329764D479BD498ACC3147D71.description: Analyze historically significant speeches (e.g., Abraham Lincoln's "Gettysburg Address," Martin Luther King, Jr.'s "I Have a Dream") to find the rhetorical devices and features that make them memorable.

3C5E360F201045118BC7FDDE084B4C4C.description: Analysis and Evaluation of Oral and Media Communications

0B61075F5BB94E86866E3A5FB58DAF78.description:
Analyze the occasion and the interests of the audience and choose effective verbal and
nonverbal techniques (e.g., voice, gestures, eye contact) for presentations.

96E62685A0274B2C88DFC81CD154BFC1.description: Produce concise notes for extemporaneous delivery.

D061E68BEA2A4038B55A72493C4C92F1.description:
Use props, visual aids, graphs, and electronic media to enhance the appeal and accuracy
of presentations.

894B312BBFDF4526B86DF6D100846D65.description:
Present and advance a clear thesis statement and choose appropriate types of proof
(e.g., statistics, testimony, specific instances) that meet standard tests for evidence, including credibility, validity, and relevance.

5CBC74960BE9408E84EDD463CF761EE4.description: Recognize and use elements of classical speech forms (e.g., introduction, first and second transitions, body, conclusion) in formulating rational arguments and applying the art of persuasion and debate.

F51248796C714D64B72D2F6CE6C6BE1F.description: Choose appropriate techniques for developing the introduction and conclusion (e.g., by using literary quotations, anecdotes, references to authoritative sources).

8B20ECC3F16E47DDA6669F0B49C796E0.description: Choose logical patterns of organization (e.g., chronological, topical, cause and effect) to inform and to persuade, by soliciting agreement or action, or to unite audiences behind a common belief or cause.

8C7B942C21A248CC87719853C06D6915.description: Organization and Delivery of Oral Communication

C7208C1D0B0C46E28B1C32D42D5ED473.description: Compare and contrast the ways in which media genres (e.g., televised news, news magazines, documentaries, online information) cover the same event.

7FC091EE4CAB4994A4DF7025BF8152C8.description: Formulate judgments about the ideas under discussion and support those judgments with convincing evidence.

014243B43EE54047AEFE772EF85E0AB6.description: Students formulate adroit judgments about oral communication. They deliver focused and coherent presentations of their own that convey clear and distinct perspectives and solid reasoning. They use gestures, tone, and vocabulary tailored to the audience and purpose.

156ADF26A436401F8C622D095DC699E5.description: Reflect appropriate manuscript requirements, including title page presentation, pagination, spacing and margins, and integration of source and support material (e.g., in-text citation, use of direct quotations, paraphrasing) with appropriate citations.

C526F4EDABE540E48A70169A53E978E9.description: Produce legible work that shows accurate spelling and correct use of the conventions of punctuation and capitalization.

8D52B9354C654FF39CEF28245F9CF40B.description: Demonstrate an understanding of proper English usage and control of grammar, para- graph and sentence structure, diction, and syntax.

820EDE11378540B895D3DF324346FC65.description: Understand sentence construction (e.g., parallel structure, subordination, proper placement of modifiers) and proper English usage (e.g., consistency of verb tenses).

0916461454E2458781BBA42837127443.description: Identify and correctly use clauses (e.g., main and subordinate), phrases (e.g., gerund, infinitive, and participial), and mechanics of punctuation (e.g., semicolons, colons, ellipses, hyphens).

69AE33989E294BD4A8CA556EFBB2A117.description: Students write and speak with a command of standard English conventions.

CCE23E77058C4A00AF16938F29E6F5FE.description: Written and Oral English Language Conventions

1CB9F4ED16CD45E996CD16EE56DCE813.description: WRITTEN AND ORAL ENGLISH LANGUAGE CONVENTIONS

149B8B0A582D47C6B1EB224E99CA3029.description: Anticipate readers' problems, mistakes, and misunderstandings.

C76AC6D8B9454798BE636E470835967D.description: Include scenarios, definitions, and examples to aid comprehension (e.g., troubleshoot- ing guide).

72E8E296400F44F89C8B2DD63112F885.description: Report information and convey ideas logically and correctly

BD839BE8C03D4DB0AAEEE625CA5ACFD4.description: Write technical documents (e.g., a manual on rules of behavior for conflict resolution, procedures for conducting a meeting, minutes of a meeting):

CAB61C7A404E4972B8931D4DDBF62351.description:
Follow a conventional style with page formats, fonts, and spacing that contribute to
the documents' readability and impact.

FB84E35BC9BF473BB67406E4855586A6.description: Use appropriate vocabulary, tone, and style to take into account the nature of the relationship with, and the knowledge and interests of, the recipients.

F9A2CA6B01844F8E84D4577A141CF7F2.description: Provide clear and purposeful information and address the intended audience appropriately.

1164DB68B00846159C486B46C0A41CFE.description: Address readers' concerns, counterclaims, biases, and expectations.

EF955FAE3BC042E1800B6A09CC63C1D8.description:
Clarify and defend positions with precise and relevant evidence, including facts,
expert opinions, quotations, and expressions of commonly accepted beliefs and logical
reasoning.

4395A672A8C943C4B17A49EB30AE672D.description:
Use specific rhetorical devices to support assertions (e.g., appeal to logic through
reasoning; appeal to emotion or ethical belief; relate a personal anecdote, case study,
or analogy).

37FE07BFD01F419481F452944F07D299.description: Structure ideas and arguments in a sustained and logical fashion.

B326012C260E460B859B0680D20919A9.description: Use technical terms and notations accurately.

356E42AD517E42FF825E16F38F8164C5.description: Anticipate and address readers' potential misunderstandings, biases, and expectations.

5081EF2F02EC422A94AC0F49C2A95BA5.description: Include visual aids by employing appropriate technology to organize and record information on charts, maps, and graphs.

A202346B90074187B689BE5C2061F4E9.description: Make distinctions between the relative value and significance of specific data, facts, and ideas.

3323F52A24E5482D869D74BC4F0921EF.description: Convey information and ideas from primary and secondary sources accurately and coherently.

0D6D8D9D9F334E17ADF6D4F31A2F7EF1.description: Marshal evidence in support of a thesis and related claims, including information on all relevant perspectives.

983B19DE58CB415681DB698E5E8054D4.description: Write expository compositions, including analytical essays and research reports:

3A01A2058952409794E8F3B9EC768953.description:
Identify and assess the impact of perceived ambiguities, nuances, and complexities
within the text.

446F1C2B360F430AA49A594782FE6AD2.description:
Demonstrate awareness of the author's use of stylistic devices and an appreciation of
the effects created.

CA2126BB01CA4CF1B578277066D6F318.description:
Support important ideas and viewpoints through accurate and detailed references to
the text or to other works.

157D7C9294D645159E2AB334D5533077.description: Demonstrate a comprehensive grasp of the significant ideas of literary works.

678A16A974574D5A908E9EE482C3C1F7.description:
Make effective use of descriptions of appearance, images, shifting perspectives, and
sensory details.

B6335B471D764B6FA77AA7E6B49878E3.description: Pace the presentation of actions to accommodate changes in time and mood.

1DF6B4DF39A442CB94C3EE53133D73ED.description:
Describe with concrete sensory details the sights, sounds, and smells of a scene and
the specific actions, movements, gestures, and feelings of the characters; use interior
monologue to depict the characters' feelings.

ABFBA32F991247DAA40B79F963CC68DE.description: Locate scenes and incidents in specific places.

125FAB002FFB4189A205D93F64893650.description: Relate a sequence of events and communicate the significance of the events to the audience.

0090CF5D714447A5A7EC0A6395E86D30.description: Write biographical or autobiographical narratives or short stories:

6764C32A057D450B99145CF1B7F52E28.description: Using the writing strategies of grades nine and ten outlined in Writing Standard 1.0, students:

5F0AD011FFE84530BC1892B46C900EC9.description:
Students combine the rhetorical strategies of narration, exposition, persuasion, and description to produce texts of at least 1,500 words each. Student writing demonstrates
a command of standard American English and the research, organizational, and drafting strategies outlined in Writing Standard 1.0.

971E70A6AF0C47CF949BFCB07C44A91C.description: Revise writing to improve the logic and coherence of the organization and controlling perspective, the precision of word choice, and the tone by taking into consideration the audience, purpose, and formality of the context.

970CA43547F4423282C60C11E5D5A004.description:
Design and publish documents by using advanced publishing software and graphic
programs.

6E5D7B44C9904BBF81DFF2F3B4E55DB4.description:
Use appropriate conventions for documentation in the text, notes, and bibliographies by
adhering to those in style manuals (e.g., Modern Language Association Handbook, The
Chicago Manual of Style).

36DF2E5A379F4B1380B7C5CA6D52E1A5.description: Integrate quotations and citations into a written text while maintaining the flow of ideas.

013BBDD123B44E3898AC9C2E607AA327.description:
Synthesize information from multiple sources and identify complexities and discrepancies in the information and the different perspectives found in each medium
(e.g., almanacs, microfiche, news sources, in-depth field studies, speeches, journals,
technical documents).

4D8A17CAEE0145199A7A8DB2B07E3B47.description:
Develop the main ideas within the body of the composition through supporting evidence
(e.g., scenarios, commonly held beliefs, hypotheses, definitions).

BA4A48A4A864458DBDE0C475565B2F9B.description: Use clear research questions and suitable research methods (e.g., library, electronic media, personal interview) to elicit and present evidence from primary and secondary sources.

894A1C10E9C34885AFAA531BEBA591E0.description: Use precise language, action verbs, sensory details, appropriate modifiers, and the active rather than the passive voice.

605ED1A6A205493F83B39339D2ECEA1C.description: Establish a controlling impression or coherent thesis that conveys a clear and distinctive perspective on the subject and maintain a consistent tone and focus throughout the piece of writing.

DBF1A07C4B3546A3B9AA11E30613EAE5.description: Students write coherent and focused essays that convey a well-defined perspective and tightly reasoned argument. The writing demonstrates students' awareness of the audience and purpose. Students progress through the stages of the writing process as needed.

B560FC8744A143C58424A03B0A4943F7.description: Analyze the way in which a work of literature is related to the themes and issues of its historical period. (Historical approach)

A3C00E0B50C4401B9360A074BD777E0D.description: Evaluate the aesthetic qualities of style, including the impact of diction and figurative language on tone, mood, and theme, using the terminology of literary criticism. (Aesthetic approach)

9A139BABAEF6449FAFD511B267A1A2F8.description: Identify and describe the function of dialogue, scene designs, soliloquies, asides, and character foils in dramatic literature.

9593E931687A4D79B2C9FBEA6C35C5D6.description: Explain how voice, persona, and the choice of a narrator affect characterization and the tone, plot, and credibility of a text.

AAD96B1370704C6897C540D32EECEA73.description: Interpret and evaluate the impact of ambiguities, subtleties, contradictions, ironies, and incongruities in a text.

9A5C1D4902104D97A9E3E129620BF4DC.description: Recognize and understand the significance of various literary devices, including figurative language, imagery, allegory, and symbolism, and explain their appeal.

0A6E36E01B964395A05E497E096DD115.description: Analyze and trace an author's development of time and sequence, including the use of complex literary devices (e.g., foreshadowing, flashbacks).

3E80261BE81D4414B609E722C627C716.description:
Compare works that express a universal theme and provide evidence to support the
ideas expressed in each work.

E1C0066A48A248469A28A9C108D738CE.description:
Determine characters' traits by what the characters say about themselves in narration,
dialogue, dramatic monologue, and soliloquy.

B9BD40C5A05940ED92CD2C8157BAA1DA.description:
Analyze interactions between main and subordinate characters in a literary text
(e.g., internal and external conflicts, motivations, relationships, influences) and explain
the way those interactions affect the plot.

024237C4E30A4B0297B34DAA7FA4E638.description: Compare and contrast the presentation of a similar theme or topic across genres to explain how the selection of genre shapes the theme or topic.

BAB407EF55FD4DDD9B0F47467B945C2B.description: Articulate the relationship between the expressed purposes and the characteristics of different forms of dramatic literature (e.g., comedy, tragedy, drama, dramatic monologue).

A2EDC14359DA434E8DD6DB9F81135FF3.description: Students read and respond to historically or culturally significant works of literature that reflect and enhance their studies of history and social science. They conduct in- depth analyses of recurrent patterns and themes. The selections in Recommended Literature, Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve illustrate the quality and complexity of the materials to be read by students.

AC17E3EC9C1D474E88503978323BE6CA.description:
Evaluate the credibility of an author's argument or defense of a claim by critiquing the relationship between generalizations and evidence, the comprehensiveness of evidence, and the way in which the author's intent affects the structure and tone of the text
(e.g., in professional journals, editorials, political speeches, primary source material).

805BFE605A2240F58481FCE39F19D26E.description: Critique the logic of functional documents by examining the sequence of information and procedures in anticipation of possible reader misunderstandings.

F914037DFC854176A03E2E6F192936A1.description:
Demonstrate use of sophisticated learning tools by following technical directions
(e.g., those found with graphic calculators and specialized software programs and
in access guides to World Wide Web sites on the Internet).

6CA532E060EF4DAD8AD95DD6FD44BA1D.description:
Extend ideas presented in primary or secondary sources through original analysis,
evaluation, and elaboration.

C3CCB04E4DAF4E378E42BDA1F8ABAA53.description:
Synthesize the content from several sources or works by a single author dealing with a
single issue; paraphrase the ideas and connect them to other sources and related topics to
demonstrate comprehension.

745F489A57AA4955BE83A61E2227DA6B.description: Generate relevant questions about readings on issues that can be researched.

59BA941C01DF4EFFB0715EADF478A3BA.description: Comprehension and Analysis of Grade-Level-Appropriate Text

BA757786FD7846C9B0228A4FDE08AA38.description:
Prepare a bibliography of reference materials for a report using a variety of consumer,
workplace, and public documents.

BABD8639858C4B3FA59A7429C5B37AC7.description:
Analyze the structure and format of functional workplace documents, including
the graphics and headers, and explain how authors use the features to achieve their
purposes.

6D576D67201240E592C9B6FEC8EF0482.description: Students read and understand grade-level-appropriate material. They analyze the organizational patterns, arguments, and positions advanced. The selections in Recom- mended Literature, Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve illustrate the quality and complexity of the materials to be read by students. In addition, by grade twelve, students read two million words annually on their own, including a wide variety of classic and contempo- rary literature, magazines, newspapers, and online information. In grades nine and ten, students make substantial progress toward this goal.

CCC5B7FE680A4609856A3B46066284A6.description: Identify Greek, Roman, and Norse mythology and use the knowledge to understand the origin and meaning of new words (e.g., the word narcissistic drawn from the myth of Narcissus and Echo).

250F9F0827B74CFB93240C5B33FF8BD7.description: Distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words and interpret the connotative power of words.

568CE2BD4A0C4006A363ABE96CC0A14F.description: Identify and use the literal and figurative meanings of words and understand word derivations.

087FC46358EE4C1F9164C801F413C63E.description: Students apply their knowledge of word origins to determine the meaning of new words encountered in reading materials and use those words accurately.

CBC6B370DD644B1AA208EC3829EEEB5F.description: Word Analysis, Fluency, and Systematic Vocabulary Development
